conclusion: There are four objects (a bowl, a clock, a pie, and a waffle) placed on slabs, and shadows (A, B, C, and D) are cast on the ground due to a light source.
The light source moves forward and above the objects.
When the light source moves forward and above the objects, shadows will shift backward relative to the objects because the light rays now strike the objects at a steeper angle.
When the light source moves forward and above the objects, shadows will become smaller as the angle of light rays becomes more vertical.
In the first image, shadows (A, B, C, and D) are cast at a noticeable angle, extending to the left and slightly backward.
In the second image, shadows have shifted backward and are closer to the objects.
In the first image, shadows are larger because the light source is at a lower angle relative to the objects.
In the second image, shadows are smaller because the light source has moved higher and forward, creating a more vertical angle of light.
When the light source moves forward and above the objects, shadows (A, B, C, and D) shift backward relative to the objects.
When the light source moves forward and above the objects, shadows (A, B, C, and D) become smaller.
